body:
Hi,
thank you. Can you add some documentation and/or a quick example?

Then I think we need a bit of a different approach.

Can we remove the jobmanager rpc address from the config file, and have the script check whether there is an entry for the jobmanager address. If not, it uses the local hostname.

I would actually prefer to have something like a `.jobmanager` file in yarn, rather than rewriting the config. Seems much cleaner.
Ah, okay. The example is in the JIRA issue (http://pastebin.com/PkcWQRkh).

Thank you for the contribution.
Why are you opening pull requests at many large (apache) projects within a few seconds?
https://github.com/zxing/zxing/pull/204 https://github.com/OryxProject/oryx/pull/23 https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/1987 https://github.com/apache/incubator-optiq/pull/7 https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/75.
Hmmmm ... I don't know why should I have a reason, it can help, I am just browser apache's project, that's it :) I'm not a bot, dont worry :D

Very good work. 20 minutes for the tests on travis is very good. 
The timing is also good because we'll merge the streaming code soon.

+1 .. good to merge.
Looks good to merge to me...
+1 good change
Looks good to me, I'll merge it...
Looks reasonable, I will merge it...
I am merging this...
Will merge
Now that all legal requirements are cleared and we are in past-release-candidate mode (again merging stuff), I will add this to the main line...

Much better that way. Thanks for the feed-back.
Just pushed the changes.

On Thu, Aug 14, 2014 at 9:10 PM, Stephan Ewen notifications@github.com
wrote:

> It also allows you to drop the workaround with the blocks and simply work
> with the default parallelism, further simplifying the example.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-flink/pull/78#issuecomment-52229325.

I think you can even further simplify it and
- Either drop the mapper that converts the numbers to 1, do the filter directly and then count, or
- Do the mapper that uses the filter's logic to convert the value to either 0 or 1, depending on the "within the unit circle" condition. Then simply sum.
Do you use tab in the patch source or is it 4 spaces?
I'm closing this pull request. The issue has been resolved by @StephanEwen.
We agreed to use single tab spaces for indentation. Due to that the code on Github does not look so compactly. Did I mix it up somewhere in the code?
Looks good, will merge...

Very nice!

Will merge...
As per our separate discussion, I think it makes sense to name the common (internal) environment differently (context for example)?
No, you were right. It caught me by surprise because most of the Java/ Scala code I have been working with use spaces for indentation.

Merged this one. Thank you!

@zentol Can you close this PR? Thanks!

This pull request has been merged, without closing the issue: https://github.com/apache/incubator-flink/commit/bbde5faef4bbf73c53c33f50276e19d69dd72a9a#diff-d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e

@warneke: Could you close the pull request for us? (We don't have any additional permissions in this repo, as it belongs to the ASF).

Thank you for the pull request.
Is there any JIRA associated with these changes? (I'm intentionally asking this question to let you know that usually have JIRA issues corresponding to pull requests)

The pull request contains a number of changes that we've done during the last two weeks and we haven't open JIRA issues for them - but will enforce this workflow in the future.

By the way how would you suggest to tag the commits then, because we'd need both the [streaming] and the [FLINK-<number>] tag for the commits, right?
I would tag them [FLINK-#issue] [streaming] . If the [FLINK] tag is first, then the scripts and bots that associate GitHub pull requests and JIRA issues will probably work.

Hello Artem and mentors,

First of all nice greetings from INRIA, France.
Hope you had an enjoyable experience in GSOC!
Thanks to Robert (rmetzger) for forwarding me here ...

At INRIA, we are starting to adopt Stratosphere / Flink.
The top-level goal is to enhance performance in User Defined Functions (UDFs) with long workflows using multiple M-R, by using the larger set of Second Order Functions (SOFs) in Stratosphere / Flink.
We will demonstrate this improvement by implementing some Use Cases for business purposes.
For this purpose, we have chosen some customer analysis Use Cases using weblogs and related data, for 2 companies (who appeared interested to try using Stratosphere / Flink )
- a mobile phone app developer: http://www.tribeflame.com
- an anti-virus & Internet security software company: www.f-secure.com
  I will be happy to share with you these Use Cases, if you are interested. Just ask me here.

At present, we are typically in the profiles of Alice-Bob-Sam, as described in [Artem's GSoC proposal](https://github.com/stratosphere/stratosphere/wiki/GSoC-2014-Project-Proposal-Draft-by-Artem-Tsikiridis).
Hadoop seems to be the starting square for our Stratosphere / Flink journey.
Same is the situation with developers in the above 2 companies :-)

Briefly,
We have installed and run some example programmes from Flink / Stratosphere (versions 0.5.2 and 0.6). We use a cluster (the grid5000 for our Hadoop & Stratosphere installations)
We have some good understanding of Hadoop and its use in Streaming and Pipes in conjunction with scripting languages (Python & R specifically)
In the first phase, we would like to run some "Hadoop-like" jobs (mainly multiple M-R workflows) on Stratosphere, preferably with extensive Java or Scala programming.
I refer to your [GSoC project map](https://github.com/stratosphere/stratosphere/wiki/%5BGSoC-14%5D-A-Hadoop-abstraction-layer-for-Stratosphere-%28Project-Map-and-Notes%29) which seems very interesting.
If we could have a Hadoop abstraction as you have mentioned, that would be ideal for our first phase.
In later phases, when we implement complex join and group operations, we would dive deeper into Stratosphere / Flink Java or Scala APIs

Hence, I would like to know, what is the current status in this direction?
What has been implemented already? In which version onwards? How to try them?
What is yet to be implemented? When - which versions?

You may also like to see [my discussion with Robert on this page](http://flink.incubator.apache.org/docs/0.6-incubating/cli.html#comment-1558297261).
I am still mining into different discussions - here as well as on JIRA.
Please do refer me to the relevant links, JIRA tickets, etc if that saves your time in re-typing large replies.
It will help us to catch up fast with the train of collective thinking in the Stratosphere / Flink roadmap, and eventually contribute to the project.

Thanks in advance,
Anirvan
PS : Apologies for using names / rechristened names (e.g. Flink / Stratosphere) as I am not sure, which name to use currently.

Hi Anirvan,
thanks a lot for getting in touch.
Robert forwarded your mail to the flink-dev mailing list and Artem and I replied there ([see Archive](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/flink-dev/201408.mbox/%3CCAAiGx18ZSW0Lfsapg_KPwmEO%2B-1TZXT0q_1OAbGRzT5At-b%3Dkg%40mail.gmail.com%3E))

I would suggest continue the discussion on the mailing list.
You can sign up [here](http://flink.incubator.apache.org/community.html#mailing-lists).

Best, Fabian

Looks good to me. 
However, FLINK-1073 does not allow to merge this PR yet. 
Once that issue is fixed, this PR can be merged.
I added some additional example in the flink-example project...

Looks good so far, I would like to merge this soon.

One question, though: Have you looked into the new dependencies (redis, memcached, ...) and checked whether they have notice files with notices?

If so, the notices may need to go into `flink-dist/src/main/flink-bin/NOTICE`.

Thanks for pointing this out, I haven't checked until now:
-  [Redis](https://github.com/antirez/redis): no NOTICE file in project root, anything similar is for their dependencies under [deps](https://github.com/antirez/redis/tree/unstable/deps). They have this [info](http://redis.io/topics/license) on their website.
- [Memcached](https://github.com/memcached/memcached): no NOTICE att all, one [COPYING](https://github.com/memcached/memcached/blob/master/COPYING) which is actually a new BSD license
-  [LevelDB JNI](https://github.com/fusesource/leveldbjni): nothing in this range. However It was important to double-check this as we're not actually depending on LevelDB, but on this related project. This is also under new BSD fortunately.
Did a rebase to amend the commit where the license error was made.
Good to merge...

Looks like a lot of work.

Two comments:
- The code seems to be incompatible with java 6: https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/34053968/log.txt
- I think the pull request contains a lot of commits (in particular duplicate messages / merge commits). Can you squash some of them to have only 1-5 commits in this PR?

Looks good to me.

Do we need to update the documentation for this change?

Sorry for the long delay. This looks like cool work, especially unifying the Accumulators and Aggregators :-)

This is interacting quite a bit with the RPC, ExecutionGraph, and JobManager/TaskManager communication (see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-1030). I am currently reworking that and would like to merge it with that part once it is done.

Okay, I agree. Let's not create mapper.

+1   that function name should include "file" somewhere. How about `readFileOfPrimitives(String path)`.

Pleaase check the headers, they are not apache compliant.
This is a very nice idea. I'll try and incorporate it into the following effort: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-1030

And updates here? Both on the usecase and on the problem that occurs if the first lines cross splits?

Otherwise I vote to close this pull request.

I have taken the delta of this patch to the pull request #36 and put it into 38cbf0b915dea175f287d7c2a627467a02d28474

Thank you for the patch!
We should probably wait with this pull request until @tillrohrmann has finished the switch over to the new logging framework.

As far as I know @markus-h is currently doing an exchange semester, so I don't expect him to have much time work on this.

I would also vote to close the pull request for now. There is still an issue in JIRA to track the progress and I just attached the changes of this PR to the JIRA issue.
I successfully looked superficially over the code ;)

I've picked up the work here to continue working on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-1032.
You can find the current work in progress here: https://github.com/rmetzger/incubator-flink/tree/pojo-nested-field-selectors

I would suggest to close this pull request. The three commits from this PR will be contained in the PR that I'm going to open.
+1 for closing this PR
Thank you for merging!

This pull request should be obsolete once #111 has been merged. This pull request requires henceforth that the configuration of the logging framework is done by providing a configuration file. If the configuration file is not provided, then the default settings are used. Currently, logback is chosen as the slf4j binding and logback set the log level to DEBUG by default and prints everything on stdout.

@rmetzger is right, I will probably not be able to finish this in the next months.
I created this pull request originally as a quick fix because it was requested by a fellow student during our project last term. So for me it is ok to close this PR.
Thanks for mergin!
Very nice. I will have a look later, but would already vote to add the small notes from your mailing list thread [1] to the docs and make it part of the PR.

i integrated my code (with some modifications, like the use of stringbuilder when deserializing) into yours and got these results:

my code:
Time taken
- String objects: 65559 Âµsecs
- String deserialization: 1498175 Âµsecs
- Binary comparison: 36816 Âµsecs

your code:
Time taken
- String objects: 65650 Âµsecs
- String deserialization: 1243583 Âµsecs
- Binary comparison: 71670 Âµsecs
Closing it since @rmetzger took over.

Wow, does that mean that your binary comparison code is faster than the regular String.compareTo(anotherString) ?

Or did I misinterpret the experiment setup?
Very cool, I love this :-)
yup, it appears to be faster than compareTo.
I have implemented your comment.
Good point Ufuk. I'll add the information to the docs.
I added the documentation.

Thanks for adding the documentation. :-)

I've checked the configuration files of the tests and bash scripts. I didn't check every single file, where you replaced the log4j logger though, but since everything is compiling and the tests are running, it should be fine (the test that is failing is unrelated to this PR, see [FLINK-1077](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-1077)).

+1 to merge. I like the new logging pattern, which now includes the thread:

```
11:33:11.842 [Nephele Executor Thread 2] INFO  org.apache.flink.runtime.execution.ExecutionStateTransition  - JM: ExecutionState set from RUNNING to FINISHING for task CHAIN DataSource (TextInputFormat (file:/var/folders/3_/h2rwvy1541g0x_m9bjpqnhfc0000gn/T/org.apache.flink.test.example) -> FlatMap (org.apache.flink.example.java.wordcount.WordCount$Tokenizer) -> Combine(SUM(1)) (3/4)
```
I'm merging this now.

Thanks for the pull request!
Just merged it.
Thanks for the fix!

PR #109 fixes FLINK-1073. 
Waiting for that one before we can proceed with this PR.

Thanks for the PR!
We decided to disable POJO expression keys for the 0.6 release, but will definitely add this feature one of the next releases.

@atsikiridis I think we can close this PR for now.

The support to run complete Hadoop Jobs requires a bit more work. At least the combiner should work.
I am waiting for comments on PR #108 which is required to add custom combiners to the Hadoop Job operation.

Parts of this PR (wrappers for iterators and collectors, dummy reporters, etc.) can be added in a new PR which addresses FLINK-1076.

I merged this PR.
@gyfora @mbalassi Thanks guys!

I had a look at this PR and found a few issues:
- it contains changes for several independent features
  - Initial value for ReduceFunction
  - Count operator
  - many cosmetic changes / documentation improvements
- my gut feeling is, that rebasing this PR onto the current master will cause many merge conflicts. It might be worthwhile to separate these issues into independent PRs to make the merging easier.
- counting for grouped datasets is done with a non-combinable GroupReduceFunction which is not vey efficient
- An initial value for ReduceFunction is only supported for AllReduce. I see that the original motivation for this (a 0-valued count for empty datasets) does not make sense for grouped ReduceFunctions, but this is not the only way an initial value could be used.

Thanks for the review. The initial value for the reduce function and the count operator are tightly connected. The reduce with initial value is the general solution, of which the count operator is a special case. Therefore, I wouldn't say that these are independent features. The refactorings are also limited to files related to the initial value reduce/count operator.

The counting for grouped data sets was a quick fix after @hsaputra's comment. We can either fix it with this PR or open a seperate issue if we want to merge it.

I think the limitation to AllReduce was the result of a discussion with you and @StephanEwen.

---

All in all, I think that we should wait for the upcoming changes to the runtime and scheduler to support the more intuitive API of simply returning the count to the user program. As you said, we might move some of the changes (like initial value reduce) to a separate issue if we find them useful.
@fhueske Ok, I will try to have the pr for FLINK-1076 soon.

Sure, the count op requires the init value, but not vice versa. I meant we could do the init value change first (which also has a separate JIRA I think) and put the count op on top.

If we wait for the runtime changes, should we just close this PR for now and extract the init value changes for a separate PR?

Sorry for the late answer. This is nice work!

We are also working on a deep integration of shipping results (also temporary intermediate results) back to the client. This will be a deep integration, used also for communicating statistics and metrics of intermediate results. The JobManager will be extended with a BLOB service to move large binary data (see #107).

Until that effort is done, your patch is a very valuable utility, so it makes sense to add it.

I would, however, prefer if it was self-contained, only in the output format. Once a method is in the `DataSet` class, we can hardly remove it from there any more. Since this is sort of a temporary (few months) workaround, it would be good to not have specialized methods for it in `DataSet`.

Do you think that is possible?
Bear in mind that the count will be given for free also when the first-class handling of intermediate results is merged.

An improvement here could be to unify the detection whether a UDF is a lambda, and the type extraction. Right now, we look up the `writeReplace` method and check for serialized lambda twice - once for detection, once for extraction.
This approach only works when using the Eclipse Java compiler. When using javac, which maven and intellij use, the generic type information is not preserved.

That seems reasonable.

+1
...  oh I did not realize that there is a tests concerning this feature...

@rmetzger can you check why the second build fails?

I can not see any connection from the error message

```
/home/travis/build.sh: line 41: 1551 Killed mvn -Dflink.forkCount=4 -B $PROFILE clean install verify

The command "mvn -Dflink.forkCount=4 -B $PROFILE clean install verify" exited with 137.
```

to my change

I think its not your fault that the test failed there. Our tests are using a lot of memory and most likely the kernel of the travis worker killed the jvm (oom killer).
I think your changes are passing the tests.

Thanks for the PR.
LGTM (did not build)

Did you check if the tests pass? There might be some dependencies on the Histogram.
Oh, indeed, I seem to have missed a test. I changed that one and now ran a {mvn test} successfully on my machine.

Integration tests are only triggered with `mvn verify`.
Not sure if there are any that depend on the changed code.

Ah okay, the more you know :smiley: 

Unfortunately, on my Windows, there seems to be an issue with the deletion of a temp file, so that I cannot actually run the whole integration tests there. On travis, it seems to be passing now, though.
When is the `web-docs-infoserver/resource-usage-detailed2.html` file being used?

It is not reachable from the main page. 

I left it there as I figured it is of no harm and might be useful for further extensions and as alternative view on the overall cluster performance.
Irrelevant because of Scala Rework Pull Request.

-1
- Documentation has not been updated to reflect the changes. (not only the scala-specific documentation, also for example this one: http://flink.incubator.apache.org/docs/0.6-incubating/run_example_quickstart.html)
- Hadoop2 builds are not passing 

Would it make sense to use tabs in the scala code as well?
Should we add something like checkstyle for scala into our maven build?

I tried integrating this into the flink-scala project for generating javadocs for scala: https://github.com/typesafehub/genjavadoc
I did the integration for the old flink-scala. Maybe you can take a look into this and see if you can get it running.
I'm currently changing the website build process to build javadocs for the whole project, so it would be nice to have javadocs for the scala API in place for the next release.
This is what I tried so far: https://github.com/rmetzger/incubator-flink/commit/875d8b07e826a337b391008af3951a6c61beb3a5
Does it have to be Javadoc? Since in Scala they normally use ScalaDoc.

It seems to be impossible to mix Scaladoc and Javadoc. Since most of our project has been written in Java, I think it would be easier and better to use Javadoc.

If its impossible to get it running, we can also add another link into our documentation, just for the Scaladoc.

But people using the Scala API would probably like to have ScalaDoc? I'll look into genjavadoc nevertheless.

For the documentation, I would like to rewrite the Java documentation to have tabs for selecting Java or Scala for the code examples. Since the concepts are exactly the same now. What do you think?

Regarding tabs in Scala source: I think it's highly unusual.

I think having only one documentation "Flink programming guide" that is language independent would be great!

I'm okay with spaces in the Scala source. We should decide for one and then enforce it using something like checkstyle.
Where does the hadoop2 build fail? Both on travis and on my machine "mvm -Dhadoop.profile=2 clean verify" works.

The status box above the comment field say "The Travis CI build failed". When clicking the "Details" button, this page appears: https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-flink/builds/35272833
But you are right, your latest commit seems to build.

I'm integrating this: http://www.scalastyle.org

I'll use the spark scalastyle config. Do you think I have to mention it anywhere? It's also Apache Licensed after all...
The build has passed. Ready to be merged, if there is no more feedback.
I added Scalastyle.
I think this can be merged. Any objections?
